Introduction.Paragraph: The equation processing system used in Open University module websites supports two equation languages: MathML (version 2) and TeX.
For example, this is a MathML equation that you could type into a forum post or wiki page:
Alternatively, you could type this LaTeX equation:
These give very similar results (or identical, if you are viewing directly as MathML):

When copying and pasting equations from other applications, MathML may be the most suitable choice. However, as the above example demonstrates, it is usually easier to use TeX when typing equations manually.

StudyNote.Heading: How to enter equations
StudyNote.Paragraph: When entering equations in MathML or TeX, always enter the equation directly into the normal text editor. Do not use the HTML view. If you enter MathML equations into the HTML view, they will not work.

Introduction.Paragraph: While our system aims to support all commands and symbols in the MathML version 2 specification, with regard to TeX, we support only a subset of AMS LaTeX commands. This document lists them.

Paragraph.i: Note: We also use the equations in this document to test our system. Some commands are included twice (demonstrating multiple possible ways to use the command), in order to help ensure that the system keeps working as expected.

tr.td: \R - do not use This method of entering certain double-struck letters currently works but is not supported in standard AMS LaTeX. Please use \mathbb{R} instead.
AmpersandThe ampersand symbol is rendered with space around it in MathML, but not in LaTeX. It may be best to avoid this symbol.
QED symbolThe AMS LaTeX QED symbol is a hollow rectangle. Many people prefer the \blacksquare command.
Negative thin space Some MathML renderers ignore negative space (e.g. Firefox prior to version 23, bug 717546).
\over - not recommended Our system does not always render \over consistently. Use \frac instead.
\choose - not recommended Our system does not always render \choose consistently. Use \binom instead.

td.ComputerCode: \biglThese commands do not render correctly in MathPlayer and should be avoided.
\displaystyle\displaystyle has no effect in this example because equations created in collaborative tools use display style by default. It should work within an inline equation.

tr.td: \not (with letter) - not recommended You can use \not with a letter, but it usually looks bad; best to restrict it to standard symbols which have a 'not' variant.

Table.TableHead: Font styleAt time of writing, Firefox only supports the bold, italic, and sans-serif variants when users choose to render as MathML. Other variants display as normal text. This is Firefox bug 114365

td.footnote: The \bf and \rm commands have been deprecated since 1994.

tr.td: array (not aligned) - do not use The \begin{array} command, without any alignment parameters, is not supported in standard AMS LaTeX. Use the version with alignment parameters.

td.ComputerCode: \begin{array}{lcr} a & b & c \\ AB & CD & EF \end{array}

InlineEquation.TeX: \displaystyle \begin{array}{lcr} a & b & c \\ AB & CD & EF \end{array}

tr.td: displaymath - do not use This environment doesn't really make sense as the equation is already within a suitable equation environment. To select display style, use \displaystyle instead.

Paragraph.i: Note: Has no effect because equations created in collaborative tools use display style by default.
